author: PlasticRice
body:
**I have this one friend I met through discord who told me he was also into trading.**

He would text me every time futures flipped to red or green and spam emotes saying "buy" or "sell."

One day, I asked him what his positions even were, and he said he owned Amazon, Tesla, JP Morgan, Apple, and even SPY and DOW Jones. I was like, what the fuck? Are you secretly a rich stock market genius?? I asked him, "How much do you even have invested?"

He said 20 dollars. He has, like, .000001 fractional shares in every company, and whenever markets tank or moon, he throws a few extra dimes in.

**What a guy.**

author: larva_lamp
body:
People here have hated TSLA since it first reached a high of $200. I agree that the speculation has gotten out of hand lately, but Tesla from day one has had powerful, motivated leadership. Elon somehow manages to pull off miracle after miracle despite the insane challenges. The cult that surrounded Apple and Steve Jobs' vision is what made it one of the world's most valuable companies today. The insane talent of Michael Jordan made the Chicago Bulls the most valuable franchise of the '90s. Elon Musk is why Tesla is so valuable. No other car company has someone like that running things. Electric cars *will* be the kind of car everyone drives in the future. Gasoline is on its way out, it's just a matter of time frame. And the electric car that everybody wants is the one that will safely and reliably drive itself while doing so in style and has a cult of personality behind it.

So yeah, the price of TSLA does indeed look insane, but there actually is some merit to it. Sadly a much better time to buy would have been when so many people were hating on it at $200.

author: the91fwy
body:
On pure performance Intel held over a decade where there was no competition.

Today there is AMD’s new Ryzen architecture which gives Intel a very good run for the money.  This chip is x86 compatible and can run software for Intel CPUs.  For simplicity let’s call this “speaking English”.

And then we have ARM, which Apple and Qualcomm are the largest firms producing those chips.  For our simplistic explication let’s say they speak Spanish.

Software for x86 (English) won’t work as is on ARM (Spanish) even if developed against the same operating system.  So it either needs to be recompiled (rewritten in Spanish) or needs to be on the fly translated (which is really slow).

Apple has twice now switched CPU architectures that are incompatible with one another and this move to ARM will be switch #3.  It takes a lot of effort to pull off such a major switch and not anger or confuse users in the process.

Once Apple moves to ARM the only real big use left for Intel is Windows PCs and the data center.  Windows 10 was ported to ARM as well and AMD has a very competitive chip for the data center.

I don’t see Intel having much relevance a few years from now.

author: namsilat
body:
A jolly good time was had by all today as SPY was largely reported to be up even though closing bell to closing bell was flat.

The 35th sector rotation in the last week was observed from tech to other tech took front seat as Apple in a stunning display of wasted productivity and dollars rallied throughout the day before reversing course to accomplish absolutely nothing.  A number of permabulls were sighted at the top of the tremendous rally wondering if it would be one day or two days until all time highs were once again revisited to relieve them of their calls.  Wall Street Bets users were overheard observing that it wouldn’t matter anyway, as those who had bought at the top would paper hand their positions into oblivion (Ticker: MGM) at market open.

In other news, certain users of Wall Street Bets had still somehow been tricked into believing they were in a bull market even though zooming out to anything other than a 5 minute chart showed an accelerating downtrend over the last two weeks.

Bears, hungry on the news of a downturn, seized the day with a startling array of puts without understanding that volatility was falling exactly as fast as their positions were expanding, leaving them with little to show for the experience but a sense of righteous indignation, a sore ass, and a more complicated tax return.

And finally, in what will likely be the feel good story of the year, Kang Gang was vaporized in a bouncy house mishap earlier today. Investigators discovered the structure had been filled with hydrogen instead of the required hot air (Ticker : NKLA).  Nothing of value was lost in the explosion.

author: SetForYou
body:
How in the world did he “hint massively” at a partnership? By posting on Twitter asking for playlist recommendations? By using a song that has been used in so many mediums over the years it could’ve been anything? I think the obvious reason there was any idea of a major partnership was the people in this reddit WANTING there to be one; it’s called Confirmation Bias, I suggest you look it up.

People were grasping at straws from every angle:

“Steve Wozniak dancing to the song on Dancing with the Stars, meaning there MUST be some Apple partnership”. 

“Used in a Disney movie from 15-20 years ago, so it MUST be a Disney partnership”

“Ted mentioned Amazon Echo in some interview, it MUST be Amazon”

Like come on... 

This kind of product is a MAJOR achievement for a technology company such as IZEA, and one that Ted should be extremely proud of. Think of it as when Facebook releases Messenger, or one of there other hugely successful products. This is the exact same scenario for Ted and IZEA Worldwide. 

There were numerous warnings given throughout the last week, including one that actually said “this could very well be a new product since it’s matching the aesthetic of all other product lines”. You and many others just chose to believe what you wanted to believe. 

That’s on you, not Ted Murphy.

author: Lumiloop
body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/porting/apps-on-arm

Microsoft is already invested in the ARM architecture, and have been showing good faith in recent years with working with competitors and the Linux community.

 I stand by my view that if Apple doesn't support Bootcamp, it would be a business decision, not a technical limitation.

1. The launch is on the 15th, and their content will span Amazon Prime, Apple TV, Comcast, Cox, SelectTV, DISH, Sling TV, Tubi, Xumo and More.

2. The newly rebranded channel (Kartoon!) will significantly expand the distribution, which currently reaches over 100M U.S. television households and over 200M users via OTT and mobile devices.

3. Big names are involved in their programming.

4. Offering happened before, and look what happened after that. Totally rocketed.

5. Genius brands has attained NASDAQ compliance.

6. People are gobbling up these cheaper shares for a reason.

author: simmerdowntherebud
body:
Quick, dirty, and oversimplified explanation: It's just a different cpu architecture. Think of it like how a car uses a certain engine. Some use a 4 cylinder, some a v6, some a V8. They do the same job (move a car), but they do it in slightly different ways. Arm processors do the same job as Intel processors (i7, i5, etc), just differently. This wouldn't be good for Intel and would likely let Apple get more vertical integration.

https://www.howtogeek.com/180225/arm-vs.-intel-what-it-means-for-windows-chromebook-and-android-software-compatibility/

Edit: typo

author: justafish25
body: A balanced portfolio doesn’t stay balanced without trimming.  Winners will slowly take larger and larger percentages as they grow faster than others.  This means that day you average a 10% gain over a year while portfolio.  Well that’s because AAPL calls made you 50% returns while DIS sank and CCL took a shit.  Well now you’re weighted heavily on a company that has been pumping.  This means if they depreciate you will feel it heavily.  Thus you trim the winners, and buy new shit or average down on something you think will recover.

author: redeyeworld
body:
Current bagholders:
Today was mediocre at best but we need to stay positive!!!! I put 25% of my savings into this at 5.10 avg and am tempted to sell EVERY major dip but when it bounces back ten minutes later (which it does..... EVERY time) I thank the stonk gods that I didn’t.

We are now FOUR TRADING DAYS from product launch, and even with all the volatility GNUS is trading at double what it was a week ago. We were fuckin ecstatic when it first hit 5. Why would anyone even think about selling before the 15th? I am thinking I’ll take a reasonable amount out upon launch just to free up some cash and leave the rest in. This has huge long term potential. Disney, Amazon, Alibaba, Apple, Stan Lee, Schwarzenegger, Warren Buffet....... 

Been a hell of a ride and I’m probably going to need a pacemaker at 25 yrs old but we’re so close!!! I will see y’all on the other side of launch! 🚀

Edit: if you’re looking to jump in- we’re trading at exactly my current average and I’m confident. Will likely not go lower until after launch. Join team GNUS!

author: ProfPragmatic
body:
> I don't know that their R&D would increase by so much that the new profit margin is completely eaten

As people have mentioned if they're switching to ARM there's a chance that compatibility with a lot of softwares like Bootcamp that businesses may rely on may be broken. That would be a deal breaker from many, unless Apple can provide replacements or a way to support them. That isn't as much of a problem with iOS because businesses aren't running business critical software on their iPhones

author: cipherous
body:
Running bootcamp for windows ARM would nullify the vast majority of cases for using bootcamp in the first place.  If you want to play games, do serious software development or pretty much any professional work, ARM is pretty much out of the question (atleast for the time being).

Keep in mind that even Apple's touchbar still doesn't have widespread adoption, I'm also not sold on apple convincing software devs to make ARM versions of software if windows is still having trouble.

author: pegasus_y
body:
the irony is that despite berkshire's great financial position and assets, their B class stock has been subpar compared to other investments, including S&P 500 low-cost index ETFs...

despite his greatness and still is, i doubt Buffett and his berkshire stock can still replicate his earlier above 20% yearly returns in the near future.

although i want him to live for another 50 years, love his joyful personality, but I doubt he can live another 20 years, ***so the most important thing in his mind right now should be BRK CEO succession***, you guys don't need to believe me, but look at his actions these years, he's been increasingly conservative the past few years, besides buying Apple stock, haven't seen any other "successful" major investments... he wants to make sure BRK is in the best financial position possible when his successor steps in. anyway it's going to be painful to see the day he steps down from BRK CEO position...

author: Cwc123
body: Imagine being a zm bear LMAO. They have competition by fb,cisco, msft, googl? What a joke! Do you really think these companies have the capital to program a video chat app, the most innovative technology in the world? And what, they will offer these services for free to their users as part of an integrated bundle of products that are used by every organization in the world? Who cares? Companies dont care about adding new costs. And what, they have security issues. ok? what company cares about securities or hackes? Thats right,none. Oh and the best one. ItS oVErValUed. no? they generated 27m income this quarter. this means that if you buy zm now, you turn a profit in 600 years. Are you really that fcking impatient? You cant wait? And so what if they had their best quarter ever and will never see anything close to that ever again? Video conferencing is the futur. Want to go play golf? lmao good one, crack a cold beer and talk on zoom. Your boss wants you to meet an important client for good first impressions? lmao fuck that, just call him on zm while wearing boxers and a suit top. no companies will have offices after this year. none. they will all use zm. everyone will work remote.

author: 1monster90
body:
You shouldn't invest money you can't afford to lose. Personally, money in the stock market is money I am considering nonexistent until 2045.   
Don't be greedy but don't be cynical either. I think you could really benefit from making a list of interesting stocks. And from that list try to pick at least 10 stocks that you find promising and buy. Even if it's just 1 share (that way you will be focused on these companies, it's not so much to make a profit than making yourself focus and research these companies. I find it easier to focus on stocks I have at least one share with that stocks I don't own at all).  


Here is my list of shares I'm watching carefully, feel free to research it.  
MSFT, V, MA, NKE, NTDOY, LOGI, SPXL, TQQQ, DOCU,  TRIP, ALGN, F, GME, APPL, NFLX, SBUX, LUV, HS, AMZN, AAL, TMUS, PG,  INTC, QCOM, PYPL, T, ATVI, RSG, FDM, AXP, CSCO, TGT, PLSE, TROW, ORCL,  FDX, CUBE, BABA, CTAS, ALK, JNJ, LLY, CB, NEE, FANG, GAMR, TWLO, TNA,  LABU, FAS, CTRE, PEP, EBAY, DFS, GE, SNQP, MS, RF, AMG, HIG, BR, BEN,  ZNGA, COR, WWE, WYNN, VT, VTI, ELY, ADBE, SQ, TWTR, CVS, CRSP, QQ, NDLS,  WU, MTRX, PUTW, TECL, GM, NYMT, MU and NDAQ .

author: mpbh
body:
I work for a 300k person company that was almost entirely remote before COVID. We tried zoom and everyone loved it, but security and cost were the biggest issues. WebEx enterprise is cheaper and more secure, but the UX blows fat dick.

If Zoom can improve their security and offer better enterprise pricing, they'll be a clear winner. Until then, Cisco is king.

author: typicaluswhitemale
body:
This graph is for people that use a flip phone.  GDP as it was calculated is now BS for the past about 10-15 years.  Buffet has traded sideways for about the last 5 years now.  It's now a global economy.  

TLDR on GDP; it only counts products/services produced DOMESTICALLY.  Thats right, where have ALL of tech been produced for the past 5-10 years?  This doesn't include things such as AMD, Cisco, Alibaba, Aliexpress, literally any type of tech mfg., 

China has tripled GDP in last 10 years.  To rely on a US GDP graph vs. value of the market is:

RETARDED.

If companies that produce all of their products in china are taken out of the stock market valuation, I will stand corrected.  Also, are companies like BABA, JD, etc. taken out too?

author: aspergillum
body:
from the prospectus

> The weight of each Index constituent is initially based on each constituent’s free-float market capitalization and then adjusted upward or downward based on a proprietary composite score calculated based on three growth-oriented fundamental factors of each company: trailing 12-month sales growth, trailing 12-month earnings per share (“EPS”) growth, and 12-month forward- looking EPS growth consensus estimates. 


>The Index is rebalanced and reconstituted annually, effective on the first Wednesday of each May based on data as of the tenth business day prior to the reconstitution date. As of March 1, 2019, the three largest Index constituents and the weights were as follows: Cisco Systems, Inc (5.33%); Amazon.com, Inc. (4.91%); Apple Inc. (4.45%).

The biggest holding is Cisco.  It's using its own criteria to buy from the S&P 500

author: MementoMori97
body:
Personally, I would go about 50-75% in a total market or S&P 500 index fund like VTI, VOO, SPY, ITOT, etc. And then use the other 25-50% in high quality companies you like and research. 

For example: 60%-VTI 20%-MSFT 10%-KO 10%XOM

(THIS IS JUST AN EXAMPLE NOT SAYING PICK THESE WITHOUT LOOKING INTO IT)

My brokerage account currently is ~40% ITOT and the rest is split pretty evenly between Nokia, a clean energy ETF and Cisco, with Cisco having the highest weighting of the three.

Just gotta do your own research and be confident in any individual stocks you pick. Index funds are much safer but still have the potential for corrections and to lose money in the near term.

author: That70sUsername
body:
No, it's not driven by a magical expectation. The high price is due to their market penetration, which is unlike any competitor.

I'm not saying it's justified, I honestly have no idea what the true value of this company is, nobody does, but the value in Zoom is so much more than a 'magical expectation'.

Tech companies have stickier customers than any other industry in history due to the incredible amounts of data they can collect.

At a global scale, both on a consumer, business and enterprise level, Zoom has daily analytics on:

- How many video conferences take place
- Who participates in them
- Whether they use chat features or just the video/audio
- How many people are in a meeting
- How close participants are geographically

Honestly, I could make this list as long as I liked, the data points are endless.

No other video conference company has such deep penetration across every area of the vidconf market. 

That mix of personal, business and enterprise penetration isn't something anyone else in the market has, and it's so incredibly valuable at a data analytics level. 

Being able to compare and contrast customer behaviours across different contexts unlocks insights that power incredible company growth (see: Facebook)

This incredible amount of data informs their future product development opportunities, meaning that it's a strong bet that Zoom is going to make better future plays in the technology space than their competitors (e.g. Google, Webex, etc).

Note again that these competitors cover an area of the market each (personal, enterprise), Zoom covers all of it and more.

When you combine that with the fact that they have already destroyed every competitor in the space on user experience and customer satisfaction, this puts them at a huge advantage over every other player in the video conference space. 

They came into this space as a startup competing against Microsoft, Cisco and Google, and they're winning by a country mile.

So when video chats move from 'schedule a call' to an all inclusive platform that handles all communications across audio/video, personal/business, etc, Zoom is going to be the best placed to dominate that huge market.

This is an equivalent shift in the Telcom industry as the one from dial phones to mobile phones. 

If you're imagining what a shift like that might look like, imagine having cameras from your TV, fridge and various 'IoT enabled' devices around your house that follow you as you talk to people.

Imagine having an affordable interactive whiteboard in your house that updates as your video partners write on their own interactive whiteboards.

Imagine it get used to plan family trips out as much as it's used to plan corporate strategies.

Imagine being able to manipulate AR models on video and share it with the world.

That all requires a central platform to harness all the data involved and turn it into a user experience. Zoom is better placed to do that than any other company in the world right now.

That is what it's price is driven by.

And all you see is people whining that they had a security breach, as though that can't be fixed (which it has).

Every company has data breaches, not every company is this well placed to dominate a market that is going to grow like wildfire over the next 20 years.

---------

Now, with all that being said, I still only have 10% of my portfolio in Zoom, even with all this going for it, every company is a 50/50 bet at best. But if I'm gonna pick 10 companies in the world to invest in, Zoom is definitely one of them.
